title: Can Christian music actually be good artistically? - Quora

response.answer_text: What type of Christian Music are you asking about? Christian Music dates back over 2,000 years and has been composed across a multitude of cultures and a variety of settings/styles. There is certainly abundance of wonderful choral and classical music that is drawn from Christian themes by composers like Palestrina, Mauchaut, Daufay, Josquin; as well as Handel, Haydn, Brahms, Bruckner, Bach; and more modern composers like Arvo Part, John Taverner. There are amazing choral groups like the Tallis Singers, Chanticleer, Hilliard Ensemble who perform a significant amount of sacred music. If you scan the globe you will also find some amazing musicians and songwriters creating Christian music in Kenya, Uganda, Egypt, Ethiopia, India, China, Russia, Ireland, Colombia and the like. My sense is that you are alluding to Christian Contemporary Music (CCM)? Here too there are some good musicians and groups creating modern Christian music. It’s not always what you are going to here of pop Christian radio stations. But you can find some interesting and well crafted worship and Christian recordings by the likes of: Gungor, The Brilliance, Enter the Worship Circle, Sojourn, Red Mountain Church, Rivers & Robots, Bifrost Arts and others.

Uh, yes.  (The Hallelujah Chorus from Handel’s Messiah) I’m a life long atheist and this thing makes me cry (sometimes.) That’s just the tip of the iceberg for phenomenal Christian music. (or did you have something more specific in mind?)

Okay, others have mentioned the great classics, but how about some modern (well, from the ‘70s) Jewish Christian music?   The group is Lamb, the best Messianic music group I’ve ever heard. And let’s not forget Godspell  Or Roy Buchanan’s “The Messiah Will Come Again”
Hi. Check out J.S. Bach's “Mass in B minor”… …then you tell me. Cheers!
Are you familiar with the body of classical religious music. It’s one helluva lot better than ‘good’.
